data.body:
That was incredibly helpful and works perfectly, didn't think it would be that simple.

However after doing some more testing with more complex models I think I might've actually found a bug. From my tests it looks like if a JSON model has more than one material, no changes will be applied to the morph targets.

Live test (same code as before): http://creativiii.com/threejs/examples/webgl_morphtargets_human2.html

Blend file: https://a.pomf.cat/oyfcdc.blend

This seems to happen even in this situation where the materials aren't even applied to the mesh by the way.

That fixed it.

Just to ask, how do you know this stuff? It's not on the Docs. Did you just learn it from the base Three.js code?

Yeah, I'm actually not sure where/if multiple material stuff is documented... 😕 I've just run into it before. The part about enabling morph targets is in docs for material subclasses (e.g. [MeshStandardMaterial](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/materials/MeshStandardMaterial)). Perhaps it should also be on the base [Material class](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/materials/Material) docs.

Last question before I completely give up on this, is there a reason why every single morph target I try only works correctly at values 0 and 1?

I tried this with a bunch of different meshes, compex and simple, and it looks like every single mesh becomes very deformed with any value that aren't 0 or 1. The deformation seems to usually be scaling related in one of the three axes.

http://creativiii.com/threejs/examples/webgl_morphtargets_human3.html

This can be checked at this live link and then inputting in the console the values to change like:
`mesh.morphTargetInfluences[0] = -.5`

I have no clue why this is happening. I've also experienced random rotations with more complex meshes.

It looks to me as if, instead of pulling vertices in the direction they're supposed to go, they instead go the opposite way all the way through the object and get pulled out on the other side, but that's just me.

If you're setting the influences to negative values, then they're probably going the opposite way you intend, yes. Normal values would be floats [0...1], although there are certainly cases to go below 0 or above 1.

It's also possible the morph targets are configured wrong in your model... if it's glTF you can debug it [here](https://gltf-viewer.donmccurdy.com/) but otherwise that requires some setup.

Here is a simpler example:

https://cdn.rawgit.com/donmccurdy/three.js/7aa389883e26af8558ede56eed3551156d869d2e/examples/webgl_morphtargets_sphere.html

I'm not setting the values to negative numbers. With only positive numbers, while setting a morphtarget to 0.5 for example, the mesh will just entirely flatten itself. If I set the morph target to 1, the mesh will reach the shape that I gave it in blender, however that shape will be mirrored to the opposite side it started as.

http://creativiii.com/threejs/examples/webgl_morphtargets_human3.html

This is using your code, as you can see it just it just refuses to work right.

I'm fairly sure my morph targets are set up right. I'm following what this tutorial does up until part 14, after which I export using the settings found [here](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/8710#issuecomment-288163037)

Maybe it's a blender problem? Are you using blender for your models? This happened to me even while using models that I didn't make myself and I downloaded from the internet so it's even more confusing.

I also tried to convert my model to gltf, however nothing seems to load even while using the exact code you posted.

http://creativiii.com/threejs/examples/webgl_morphtargets_human4.html

Ok, yeah the effect of the influence value is just to interpolate between two shapes, so it entirely depends on what you're exporting from Blender... if `-0.5` works for you that's fine, too.

> I also tried to convert my model to gltf, however nothing seems to load even while using the exact code you posted.

That's a glTF 1.0 model, which would require LegacyGLTFLoader and doesn't support morph targets anyway:

![screen shot 2017-11-17 at 11 29 16 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1848368/32965185-aaad5c48-cb8a-11e7-8c2e-b626736ce08d.png)

OBJ doesn't support morph targets also, so even a new version of OBJ2GLTF would not work. My model was created with https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter/.
^I saw that error by setting a breakpoint, otherwise you'd need to set pass `onError` handler when calling `loader.load(onSuccess, undefined, onError)`

> Ok, yeah the effect of the influence value is just to interpolate between two shapes, so it entirely depends on what you're exporting from Blender... if -0.5 works for you that's fine, too.

-0.5 doesn't work, that's the problem. I can't have intermediate shapes at all.

However it seems like glTF does work as intended, however I am having some trouble exporting big meshes with blender, the program doesn't crash but it's either taking a very long time or not working at all.
I'll keep waiting and see what happens.

Are there any specific settings I should use or do are the default ones okay?

Thank you for all the help so far by the way, you're a saint.

> Are there any specific settings I should use or do are the default ones okay?

I assume normal use of Blender shape keys should work with glTF morph targets, but i'm not too familiar with Blender honestly.
I think any remaining issues are not related to JSONLoader, so will close this in favor of #12595 if that's ok.
